subject: Re: [junit] How do i check if i am getting right output
msgSnippet: ... I m guessing Robert is thinking of the fact that a PrintStream or PrintWriter gives a platform-specific line separator whenever you invoke println().
messageBody:
--- Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:

> Robert Watkins wrote:
>
> > Certain output streams automatically convert \n to the line
> seperator
> > of the platform you are on.
>
> Really? Which ones?

I'm guessing Robert is thinking of the fact that a PrintStream or
PrintWriter gives a platform-specific line separator whenever you
invoke println(). However Robert, that has no effect on any \n or \r
which is passed directly into a print(), println() or write() as part
of the input string or array. Or are you thinking of something else?

- Jim Yingst

> That's certainly not standard behavior, and it's
> not
> true of System.out, which is the stream at issue here.
>
> In general code should not be written to depend on the system line
> separator. That worked well when programs and data spent their entire
>
> lives on one computer, or perhaps a few computers all running the
> same
> OS. In the world of the Internet and Java, that's no longer true.
> Programs should explicitly specify the line separator character(s)
> they
> write or read. Their output should not vary from one platform to the
> next.
>
> --
